Home Gallery Slideshow Solar System Space //Planets Mercury Venus Earth Mars Jupiter Saturn Uranus Neptune The Earth is the third planet from the sun. The Earth is separated by distinct layers with a core, mantle and crust. Imagine Earth as a chocolate-covered cherry. If you stick a pencil directly through the Earth at the point of rotation, these two points are the North and South poles. Geographically speaking, it’s where lines of longitude meet. Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system – only slightly larger than Earths Moon. Even though Mercury is closer to the Sun, Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system. Mars is sometimes called the Red Planet. It is red because of rusty iron in the ground. Jupiter is the biggest planet in our solar system. Jupiter is covered in swirling cloud stripe Like fellow gas giant Jupiter, Saturn is a massive ball made mostly of hydrogen and helium. Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun, and has the third-largest diameter in our solar system It is made of a thick soup of water, ammonia, and methane over an Earth-sized solid center.
Lions are the only social big cats and live in groups called prides. A pride can consist of up to 30 lions. Elephants are the largest land animals, with males weighing up to 6 tons. They have a highly developed social structure and display complex behaviors. Cheetahs are the fastest land animals, capable of reaching speeds up to 70 mph (112 km/h) in short bursts to catch their prey. Dolphins are highly intelligent marine mammals known for their playful behavior. They use echolocation to navigate and find food. The bald eagle is a majestic bird of prey and a symbol of the United States. It has a wingspan of up to 7 feet (2.1 meters) and builds the largest nests of any bird species.
